docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is bad enough that people who wear eye shades instead of stethoscopes now make medical treatment decisions for a large and growing percentage of the public, but now it appears in ''A New Transplant Frontier: Intestines'' on Oct. 31. Proponents justify the $300,000 procedure because it should pay for itself in two years, by replacing intravenous feeding that costs $150,000 a year.
docs.abstract: Steven Finell letter on October 31 article holds expensive medical procedures that restore patients to health, ease discomfort or extend their lives should be available to all regardless of insurance or wealth

docs.lead_paragraph: Focused to the end on his message, Vice President Al Gore persevered Monday through a 30-hour, seven-city assault on the closely contested states that will determine whether his 13-year pursuit of the presidency culminates in a ''cold driving rain'' or a ''shaft of golden sunlight.'' Throughout the campaign, Mr. Gore has portrayed himself as more vigorous than his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and he drove that theme home today with the help of a manic schedule. After a rally at the airport in Waterloo, Iowa, that ended at 1 a.m. Monday, he began again at 5:30 a.m. at a John Deere factory there, where he shook hands with workers and gave interviews in the dark to three television networks.

headline.main: Campaign Ends; Now the Voters Will Have Their Say

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore ends 13-year pursuit of presidency with with 30-hour, seven-city assault on closely contested states; campaigns in Florida, Missouri, Michigan, Tennessee, Iowa, driving home message that he is more vigorous that opponent Gov George W Bush; his aides seem neither confident nor despondent; acknowledge most national polls show Bush with small lead, but are heartened by positive results in Florida, Pennsylvania and Michigan with crucial Electoral College votes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a 40-year-old student who has returned to school to study nursing, I can honestly say the only reason I've ever avoided a doctor was lack of insurance or inadequate funds (''Why People Avoid Doctors''). To pay for health care out of pocket, as I did three years ago with kidney stones, can be as debilitating as the illness itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT OXFORD: ARSON SUSPECTED IN FOREST FIRE -- A suspicious fire in the Naugatuck State Forest involved more than two-thirds of the forest over the weekend but was under control yesterday, the authorities said. Naugatuck's fire chief, Kerry Flaherty, said the fire was confined to 250 acres of the 365-acre forest, which borders Waterbury to the south. The fire began around noon Friday at the edge of the main access road into the forest, he said. It is being investigated as a possible arson because suspicious fires have previously started in the same area, he said. (NYT) MASHANTUCKET: INDIAN OFFICIALS OUSTED -- The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which owns the Foxwoods Casino, chose two new tribal council members on Sunday. In the election, for three of the council's seven seats, two incumbents were ousted and a third, Michael J. Thomas, was re-elected. Members of the Mashantucket Pequot tribe elected Charlene R. Jones, assistant executive director of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center, and Fatima C. Dames, a tribal council staff member, to the tribe's ruling body. They will replace Gary A. Carter and Antonio M. Beltran. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT) HARTFORD: STATE CHANGES DIPLOMA CRITERIA -- The state is revising the test for high school dropouts getting their diplomas under the General Educational Development program, or G.E.D., as school systems nationwide step up graduation standards. Starting in 2002, students will have to write more, solve more complicated math problems and analyze material like economic charts and editorial cartoons to earn their G.E.D. ''It's important that the standard be raised and be consistent with what students in high school who do four years are subjected to,'' said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the State Department of Education. ''It should not become an incentive for students to drop out because the test is easy.'' (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the final major rally of his campaign, Ralph Nader issued a populist call for a sweeping ''shift of power'' from big business to the downtrodden and disenfranchised, and he urged the country to vote its conscience, not its fears. ''A vote for your hopes, a vote for your dreams, a vote for higher expectation levels of what our country can become and what it can mean to the world,'' Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, said today before more than 10,000 people at the MCI Arena here. ''Those are the votes that you need to register, not a lesser of two evils where, at the end of the day, you're stuck with evil.''

headline.main: 10,000 Turn Out to Hear Nader Urge 'Shift in Power'

docs.abstract: Green Party candidate Ralph Nader holds finally rally of his campaign in Washington, DC, where he issues populist call for sweeping shift of power from big business to downtrodden and disenfranchised; urges country to vote its conscience, not its fears; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN September 1999, Kathleen Rotter -- who had been the special education administrator in the Hillsborough School District for eight trying years -- wanted out. Dr. Rotter, who today is an assistant professor of special education at the College of New Jersey, looks back on those years with a sadness tinged with weariness: There was the threat of litigation, the telephone messages from irate parents, the constant crisis atmosphere.

headline.main: From the Classroom To the Trenches

docs.abstract: Article on critical shortage of special education administrators and directors at schools throughout New Jersey since passage in 1975 of Individuals With Disabilities Education Act, which guarantees free and appropriate public education for all disabled students; educators and administrators comment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton ordered the Labor Department today to quickly ensure a ''fair and unbiased'' appeals process for those for whom coverage was denied or delayed under private health insurance plans. But Mr. Clinton said that his action did not go far enough and that it was up to Congress to provide more health care protections and up to voters to make sure Congress acted.

headline.main: Clinton Seeks New Rules To Expand Patient Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: Education Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks both favor increased federal spending for education, although they differ on the degree of that increase. Mr. Corzine, who calls for ''universal preschool,'' favors doubling the national enrollment in Head Start, the prekindergarten program, to include all eligible children. Mr. Franks favors a lesser increase of up to $2.5 billion over eight years.

headline.main: For Corzine and Franks, Different Paths to Often-Similar Destinations

docs.lead_paragraph: Education With New Yorkers citing education as a major concern, Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both embraced the issue as a top priority in the Senate race. But Mrs. Clinton's education proposals are similar to those of the powerful teacher unions that support her, while Mr. Lazio is more focused on wooing the suburban residents whose votes he needs. He has joined other Republicans in stressing the importance of local control over education spending and policy.

headline.main: Clinton and Lazio Differ on School Aid, Social Security and Tax Cuts

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no time like the present -- unless, of course, the topic is unpleasant -- like planning for one's own long-term care. A recent national survey of 1,002 adults 35 to 74 years old found that 23 percent would worry about their long-term care needs ''when the time comes'' and that 10 percent were ''not sure'' how they would pay for their care. The poll was commissioned by the MetLife Mature Market Institute.

headline.main: A Look Ahead to Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Metlife Mature Market Institute study finds 31 percent of adults surveyed say they will pay for their long-term care with insurance, while 23 percent say they will worry about such need when the time comes (S)
